domains.name: User Interface Design
domains.description: Artifacts and specifications that define the visual, interactive, structural, and accessibility rules used to render the Product’s experience consistently and deterministically in code.

terms.name: User Interface
terms.definition: The visual and interactive layer through which users view information and perform actions in the Product.
terms.description: Represents the concrete manifestation of experience design decisions, combining layout, components, styling, and interaction behavior.

terms.name: Design System
terms.definition: A structured set of rules, tokens, and reusable UI artifacts governing visual and interactive behavior across the Product.
terms.description: Provides a single source of truth for UI consistency, enabling scalable implementation and preventing design and code divergence.

terms.name: Design System Foundation
terms.definition: The base design rules and primitives used across the User Interface, including color, typography, spacing, layout grid, elevation, and interaction states.
terms.description: Defines the foundational visual language that all components and layouts must adhere to.

terms.name: Design Tokens
terms.definition: Atomic, named values representing visual properties such as color, spacing, typography, radii, elevation, and motion.
terms.description: Provides implementation-ready primitives that can be directly consumed by code to ensure visual consistency and themeability.

terms.name: Theme Modes
terms.definition: Defined visual themes such as light, dark, or high-contrast modes implemented through token sets.
terms.description: Defines how the interface adapts visually under different user or system preferences while preserving structural consistency.

terms.name: UI Component
terms.definition: A reusable, self-contained UI element with defined structure, behavior, and purpose.
terms.description: Acts as a building block used to assemble screens and layouts, enabling reuse and predictable behavior.

terms.name: UI Component Interface Specification
terms.definition: A detailed specification defining a UI Component’s structure, props, configurable options, and usage rules.
terms.description: Defines how a component is consumed in code, including required and optional properties and constraints.

terms.name: UI Component Interaction Specification
terms.definition: A structured definition of how a UI Component responds to user actions, system events, and state changes.
terms.description: Specifies interaction behavior such as hover, focus, loading, disabled, and error responses at the component level.

terms.name: UI Component Architecture
terms.definition: A structured model of UI Components, their relationships, dependencies, and composition patterns.
terms.description: Defines how components are organized and combined to form higher-level UI structures.

terms.name: UI Component Inventory
terms.definition: A structured list of all UI Components used in the Product, including purpose and usage scope.
terms.description: Provides a complete overview of available components to prevent duplication and uncontrolled growth.

terms.name: Component Props Contract
terms.definition: A formal definition of supported component properties, their types, defaults, and constraints.
terms.description: Ensures predictable component usage and strong typing, preventing ad-hoc or invalid configurations.

terms.name: Component State Model
terms.definition: A definition of all valid internal and visual states a UI Component can assume and the transitions between them.
terms.description: Enumerates component states such as default, hover, focus, loading, disabled, and error to support consistent behavior.

terms.name: Component Variants Matrix
terms.definition: A structured enumeration of supported component variants such as size, tone, density, or style.
terms.description: Prevents uncontrolled variant creation by explicitly listing allowed variations and their intent.

terms.name: Accessibility Rules
terms.definition: A set of enforceable rules defining accessibility requirements such as ARIA usage, keyboard support, focus order, and contrast.
terms.description: Ensures the UI is usable by people with disabilities and compliant with accessibility standards.

terms.name: Responsive Breakpoints and Layout Rules
terms.definition: Defined viewport breakpoints and layout adaptation rules used to render the UI across devices.
terms.description: Specifies how layouts and components adapt to different screen sizes to ensure consistent usability.

terms.name: UI Layout Pattern
terms.definition: A reusable structural template defining the arrangement and hierarchy of UI sections on a screen.
terms.description: Defines common layout compositions used to assemble screens consistently and efficiently.

terms.name: Content Guidelines
terms.definition: Rules governing text length, formatting, truncation, localization, and content fallback behavior in the UI.
terms.description: Prevents layout breakage and inconsistent copy by defining content constraints and formatting rules.

terms.name: Screen UI Composition Specification
terms.definition: A mapping that defines how screens are assembled from layout patterns and UI components.
terms.description: Bridges experience-level screen structures with concrete component and layout usage for implementation.

terms.name: UI Motion Rules
terms.definition: Defined rules for animations and transitions, including duration, easing, and reduced-motion handling.
terms.description: Ensures motion is consistent, accessible, and does not interfere with usability or performance.

terms.name: Component-to-Code Mapping
terms.definition: A mapping between UI Components and their concrete code implementations, modules, and dependencies.
terms.description: Enables coding agents to locate, reuse, and validate component implementations deterministically.
